lead_paragraph: A wave of deadly suicide bombings in the quiet town of Al Qaa has strained a tenuous coexistence between residents and newcomers fleeing Syria’s civil war.

byline.original: By BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

headline.print_headline: After Attacks, Lebanese Christian Town Casts Wary Eye on Refugees
headline.main: After Attacks, Lebanese Christian Town Casts Wary Eye on Syrian Refugees

snippet: A wave of deadly suicide bombings in the quiet town of Al Qaa has strained a tenuous coexistence between residents and newcomers fleeing Syria’s civil war....
abstract: Residents of Al Qaa, along with those in other towns across Lebanon, are wary of Syrian refugees after two suicide attacks kill five people and wound dozens of others; Lebanon has world’s highest refugee count per capita, and residents complain that it is not easy to tell difference between refugee and terrorist.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
